Genesis.author: Moses (traditional)
Genesis.context: First book of Torah, covers creation, fall, flood, and patriarchs Abraham, Isaac, Jacob, and Joseph

Exodus.author: Moses (traditional)
Exodus.context: Israelite slavery in Egypt, Moses, ten plagues, exodus, Red Sea crossing, Ten Commandments

Tobit.author: Unknown
Tobit.context: Story of Tobit, his son Tobias, and the angel Raphael. Emphasizes prayer, almsgiving, and proper burial
Tobit.whyDisputed: Not in Hebrew Bible; added to Septuagint. Protestants consider it apocryphal

Judith.author: Unknown
Judith.context: Story of Jewish widow Judith who saves her people by beheading Assyrian general Holofernes
Judith.whyDisputed: Historical inaccuracies; not in Hebrew Bible; considered fiction by many scholars

Wisdom.author: Unknown (attributed to Solomon)
Wisdom.context: Wisdom literature written in Greek, emphasizes immortality of the soul and divine wisdom
Wisdom.whyDisputed: Written in Greek, not Hebrew; not in Jewish canon; Hellenistic influence

Sirach.author: Jesus ben Sira
Sirach.context: Also called Ecclesiasticus. Wisdom literature covering ethics, relationships, and proper conduct
Sirach.whyDisputed: Not in Hebrew Bible initially; later found in Dead Sea Scrolls fragments

Baruch.author: Attributed to Baruch (Jeremiah's scribe)
Baruch.context: Confession of sins, wisdom poem, and encouragement to exiled Jews
Baruch.whyDisputed: Not in Hebrew Bible; written after Baruch's time; composite work

1 Maccabees.author: Unknown
1 Maccabees.context: Historical account of Maccabean revolt against Seleucid Empire (167-134 BC)
1 Maccabees.whyDisputed: Historical rather than prophetic; not in Hebrew Bible

2 Maccabees.author: Unknown (epitome of Jason of Cyrene)
2 Maccabees.context: Parallel account of Maccabean revolt with theological emphasis on resurrection and martyrdom
2 Maccabees.whyDisputed: More theological than historical; contains prayers for the dead

1 Enoch.author: Multiple authors (pseudepigraphical)
1 Enoch.context: Apocalyptic visions attributed to Enoch. Describes fallen angels, heavenly journeys, and end times
1 Enoch.whyDisputed: Excluded from most canons; quoted in Jude 14-15; canonical in Ethiopian Orthodox Church

Jubilees.author: Unknown (pseudepigraphical)
Jubilees.context: Retelling of Genesis and Exodus with additional details, emphasizes calendar and law
Jubilees.whyDisputed: Not in any major canon; found in Dead Sea Scrolls; considered authoritative by some ancient Jews

Jasher.author: Unknown
Jasher.context: Mentioned in Joshua 10:13 and 2 Samuel 1:18. Current versions likely medieval compilations
Jasher.whyDisputed: Original lost; current versions are medieval forgeries or reconstructions

2 Enoch.author: Unknown (pseudepigraphical)
2 Enoch.context: Slavonic apocalypse describing Enoch's journey through ten heavens
2 Enoch.whyDisputed: Survives only in Slavonic; not in any major canon

3 Maccabees.author: Unknown
3 Maccabees.context: Story of persecution of Jews in Egypt under Ptolemy IV, not related to Maccabees
3 Maccabees.whyDisputed: Misnomer (not about Maccabees); historical accuracy questioned

4 Maccabees.author: Unknown
4 Maccabees.context: Philosophical discourse on reason and martyrdom using Maccabean examples
4 Maccabees.whyDisputed: Philosophical treatise rather than historical narrative

Psalms of Solomon.author: Unknown (attributed to Solomon)
Psalms of Solomon.context: 18 psalms reflecting on Roman conquest and messianic hope
Psalms of Solomon.whyDisputed: Not in any major canon; pseudepigraphical

Didache.author: Unknown
Didache.context: Teaching of the Twelve Apostles. Early church manual on ethics, baptism, Eucharist, and church order
Didache.whyDisputed: Not considered inspired scripture; valuable for understanding early church practices

1 Clement.author: Clement of Rome
1 Clement.context: Letter from Roman church to Corinthian church addressing division and rebellion
1 Clement.whyDisputed: Early and valuable but not considered inspired; nearly made it into canon

Shepherd of Hermas.author: Hermas
Shepherd of Hermas.context: Apocalyptic visions and moral teachings. Very popular in early church
Shepherd of Hermas.whyDisputed: Too late to be apostolic; allegorical style; nearly made it into canon

Epistle of Barnabas.author: Unknown (not Barnabas)
Epistle of Barnabas.context: Allegorical interpretation of Old Testament and Christian ethics
Epistle of Barnabas.whyDisputed: Not by Barnabas; allegorical method questioned; nearly made it into canon

Gospel of Thomas.author: Unknown (attributed to Thomas)
Gospel of Thomas.context: Collection of 114 sayings of Jesus. Gnostic influence debated
Gospel of Thomas.whyDisputed: Gnostic tendencies; late date; not apostolic; contradicts canonical gospels

Polycarp to Philippians.author: Polycarp of Smyrna
Polycarp to Philippians.context: Letter from early church father to Philippian church on faith and conduct
Polycarp to Philippians.whyDisputed: Valuable early witness but not considered inspired scripture
